Title: Besser Mfg. Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Companies manufactured concrete block-making machines. Government sues for Section 2 and Section 4 violations related to the monopolization of the interstate concrete machine making market by monopolizing patent licenses. Appeal the order to issue patent licenses under a fair and reasonable rate and allow current lessees to acquire machinery. Supreme Court says remedies are fair and traditional and that trial judge has discretion to impose remedies.

Title: U.S. v. Oregon State Medical Soc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Involves insurance contracts that are associated with panels of doctors that formed a non-profit to provide medical services (cooperate on a fee basis or that associate themselves on a full or part-time basis).  Government sues such organizations under Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. District Court says there is no evidence and dismisses. Government appeals. Supreme Court dismissess appeal as a matter of fact and that there is no concerted refusal to deal or division of geographical markets by part of the non-profit.

Title: U.S. v. New Wrinkle, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Section 1 lawsuits as conspiration to fix minimum prices in all of the wrinkle finish industry by means of patent license agreements that established minimum prices for the licensees of the patent. District Court dismissed the Complaints and Government appealled. Supreme Court reverses and says that a patent does not grant the owner a clear power to violate antitrust laws and that it was clear that there was an impact on interstate commerce.

Title: Far East Conference v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Na approved association of shipping companies, that has been approved by the US Shipping Board, agreeed to minimum prices and others (two level freight rates). US sues for Section 1 and 2 violation. District Court dismisses because should have first gone to the Administrative body. Supreme Court confirms that it should be gone first to the Board.

Title: Hughes v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Connectd to the Paramount Pictures case, which ordered movie exhibiting companies from distribution companies. District company then ordered the divestiture and Hughes and government entered a consent decree, hughes did not comply, government ordered the sale within 2 years and Hughes appealled as unreasonable. Supreme Court agrees that such a order would constitute a change in the consent decree.

Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Ruberoid Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discussing whether a company that was one of the largest manufacturerrs of asphalt and asbestos roofing materials would price-discriminate customers in violation of the Robinson-Patman Act. FTC ordered the company to stop the price discrimination. Court of appeals affirmed the condemnation but modified part of the order. Both parties appeal. Supreme Court confirms the Circuit Court Ruling

Title: Times-Picayune Pub. Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses a tying case where buyers of advertisement had to buy advertising slots in both the morning and evening newspapers of the main publisher in New Orleans. US sues as violation of Section 1 and Section 2 of the Sherman Act. District Court enjoins the joint-acquisition of the ads. Supreme Court says there is no tying because the products and the market are the same (so there is no leverage). Also says that there is no evidence that the contractual restrictions negatively handcapped its main competitor. Reverses for lack of evidence of actual anticompetitive effects

Title: Toolson v. New York Yankees, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discussess again whether baseball is exempt from antitrust laws because it is not interstrade trade or commerce. Supreme Court reaffirms the exemption, says it is something for legislation to correct. This case discussess reverse clauses in contracts that prevent players from freely moving around

Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Motion Picture Advertising Service Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: MPA had exclusive contracts with 40% of cinemas in areas where it operates, and together the three major companies had exclusivity over advertising films in almost 75% of cinemas. FTC sues for unfair methods of competition under Section 5 of the FTC act, claiming the exclusivity was enabling it to monopolize the film distribution business. Remedy limits exclusivity contracts to one year. Circuit court reversed. Supreme Court sides with the FTC, saying there is ample evidence of impact on the market and that the appropriate duration of the exclusivity contract is for the FTC to decide.

Title: Automatic Canteen Co. of America v. Federal Trade Commission
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Robinson-Patman claim by the FTC, accusing a large candy manufacturer and seller in the US of charging different prices among purchasers. FTC says it does not need to consider cost, which is the real discussing here: whether plaintiffs must also prove differences in prices given differences in costs. Circuit Court agrees. Court reverses, saying that sellers can use cost justifications as justifications to differences in prices that otherwise would have been illegal, so that simply showing difference in prices is not enough to establish a prima facie case.

Title: U.S. v. Employing Plasterers Ass'n of Chicago
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: DoJ accuses a trade association of plastering contractors, a local labor union and the Union's president of organizing a cartel in violation of Section 1. Supreme Court says it was, and that together they controlled 60% of the market. Defendants implemented the cartel by withholding inputs. This woud impact interstate markets for inputs at least.

Title: Partmar Corp. v. Paramount Pictures Theatres Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses Res Judicata in an antitrust case, on whether a company can bring a treble damages complaint on top of another dispute that resulted in a settlement. SC Confirms it cannot. (it is res judicata)

Title: Theatre Enterprises, Inc. v. Paramount Film Distributing Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Theatre inc. files a lawsuit for treble damages against Paramount for restricting the first-run pictures in downtown baltimore theaters. Jury sided with defendants, and so did the Supreme Court.

Title: U.S. v. Employing Lathers Ass'n of Chicago and Vicinity
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Lawsuit against Lathing contractors and an association for violation of Section 1 of the Sherman Act, that would totally limit competition in the Chicago Area. Distrct Cout affirms no interstate business was impacted and there was no clear cause of action on which there can be relief. SC disagrees, affirming there was and using the justification of the Plasters case.

Title: United Shoe Machinery Corp. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US brings antitrust lawsuit under section 4 of the Sherman Act. Not clear what the dispute is. Supreme Court sides with Government

Title: U.S. v. Borden Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sues 10 Chicago diaries, saying they conspired to monopolize the sale of fluid milk to wholesale customers in the Chicago Area in violatoin of the Sherman and the price discrimination part of the Clayton Act. District Court dismissed saying there was no conspiracy and former decree already prohibited the conduct in question. Supreme Court agrees there is no evidence of conspiracy.

Title: United States v. Shubert
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Involves exclusive contracts and other discriminatory provisions in the booking of legitimate attractions throughout the US. Defendants were the largest suppliers of these service and would be blocking potential competitors. US sues for Section 1 and 2 violation. District Court dismisses as not impacting trade or commerce among several states. Supreme Court says defendants are clearly within the scope of the Sherman Act

Title: United States v. International Boxing Club of N.Y.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Government argues defendants organized a conspiracy to control the promotion, exhibition, broadcasting and other distribution of professional boxing in the US by celebrating exclusive contracts. Defendants claim exemption  because fights would not be "interstate" but local, following the MLB and other cases. District Court agrees. Supreme Court reverses.

Title: U. S. v. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Famous DuPont Cellophane case. Government alleges that DuPont was monopolizing the sale of cellophane in the US, in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act. DuPont had a 75% market share, but DuPont alleges that it cannot control the power of the product because of competiton, as other packaging materials compete with Cellophane and DuPont would only have a 20% share in those. Supreme Court sides with DuPont, affirming that cellophane compete with other wrapping materials.

Title: U.S. v. McKesson & Robbins, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Company was a large manufacturere of drugs, and sold them to retailers through its own wholesale and through independent wholesale businesses. It had a minimum "fair price" clause on its sales, that applied to both its wholesale business and independent ones. Government sues for illegal price fixing under Section 1. District Court sides with defendants, affirming that this was not a per se violation absent other restraints of competition. Supreme Court reverts.

Title: Radovich v. National Football League
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether Football is subject to antitrust laws or can be exempt like the MLB. Court affirms that there is no exemption

Title: U.S. v. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US challenged DuPont's acquisition of a 23% stake in General Motors under Section 7 of the Clayton Act. Question is on whether DuPont's leadership position in the amrket for automotive finishes and fabrics is because of its merits or because of its vertical relationship. This was the first challenge to a vertical acquisition of stock. District Court dismissed. Supreme Court affirms that the relationship is very important for the finishes market, given the large size of GM (40% or more of cars at the time). In addition, also holds that the Government is not foreclosed from brining cases to challenge acquisitions decades after the acquisition had elapsed. Supreme Court holds that the likelyhood of foreclosure was clear since the acquisiton (it was even the intention) and that the parties had acted upon it. Orders the District Court to assess what is the appropriate remedy.

Title: Lawlor v. National Screen Service Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether a cause of action for treble damages is barred by a previous settlement between plantiffs and some of the defendants. District and Circuit Court affirmed it was barred. Supreme Court disagrees because: (i) cause of action is different; (ii) defendants are different. Reverses

Title: Northern Pac. Ry. Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Northern Pacific held large grants of land, connected to the areas around its tracks. Northern Pacific leased much of this land, but required by contract that the lessee used only its railroads to ship goods. US sues as violation of Section 1 of the Sherman Act. District Court enjoined the "preferential routing" clauses. Railroad appeals. Supreme Court affirms, saying this was clearly a tying arrangement.

Title: Nashville Milk Co. v. Carnation Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Question is on whether plaintiffs can sue for treble damages under Section 3 of the Robinson-Patman act when companies sell at "unreasonably low prices". The question is on whether Section 3 of the Robinson-Patman act is implicitly part of the Sherman Act for purposes of treble damages under the Clayton Act. Supreme Court affirms it is not.

Title: Federal Maritime Bd. v. Isbrandtsen Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discussion on whether the Maritime Board can operate a dual-rate system for the tonnage of cargo between the US and Japan. The Board has a conference (association) of companies that operate the route, and Isbrandtsen has been gaining market share by discounting the prices of the conference. The Conference then asked the board to impose a dual rate system, that allows it to retaliate Inbrandsen prices. The company then sues the Board for allowing it. The question is on whether the Board can approve prices in a way that prevents competition. The Court concludes that the approval was per se illegal, and a way for companies operating in the conference to stiffle competition from a smaller entrant.

Title: Klor's, Inc. v. Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Smaller retail store sues larger chain for discrimination and conspiring to either not sell goods or sell them at highly unfavorable prices, driving the smaller store out of business. Sues for Section 1 and 2 violation. District Court grants summary judgement, said it was purely a private quarrel, with no impact on competition as many other stores remained. Circuit Court affirmed. Supreme Court reverses, saying that group boycotts and other similar conduct has long been deemed a violation of the Sherman Act, as it can lead to a "monopolistic tendency" in commerce and the fact that only a small merchant is impacted is not reason to dismiss. Monopolies can arise out of the elimination of small businesses, one at a time. Reverts

Title: Kelly v. Kosuga
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses a contract to buy and sell onions among small suppliers in the Illinois. Petitioner defaulted on the contract, but then claimed that the contract was in violation of the Sherman Act as an agreement to fix prices (there was some strong bargaining involved). District Court and Circuit Court affirm the original contract and the default. Supreme Court affirms that unless it is a clear violation of the Sherman Act, Federal law cannot be used to simply waived lawful obligations assumed under contract (and under State law).

Title: International Boxing Club of N. Y., Inc. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Following early Supreme Court decision, district Court finds that Interntaional Boxing Club was in violation of antitruts laws and order the dissolution of two corporate appellants and redesigning the market for professional world championship boxing. Appellants appeal arguing that relevant market was wrongly defined (too narrow) and remedies too intrusive. Supreme Court maintains the District Court decisions.

Title: Melrose Distillers, Inc. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Petitioners were wholly owned subsidiaries of a larger company, and were accused of conspiring to monopolize or attempting to monopolize commerce in violation of Sections 1 and 2. Following the indictement, they were dissolved and the assets where then transferred to a new company under the same ownership. They then moved to dismiss the indictment based on the dissolution. District Court denied the motion and Circuit Court affirmed. Supreme Court affirms, saying that the "person" did not "cease to exist" under State law, so that the prosecution should be abated.

Title: U.S. v. Radio Corp. of America
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Companies (NBC and RCA) agreed to acquire and exchange a Cleveland Television Station for one in Philadelphia. The exchange was approved by the FCC. The US then sues as violation of Section 1 and 4 of the Sherman Act. Question is whether the FCC approval preempets the US Federal Antitrust lawsuit. SC says that FCC has no exclusive powers to decide on antitrust issues and reverses.

Title: Minneapolis & St. L. Ry. Co. v. U. S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Some railway companies acquired a smaller railway and submited for approval of the ICC. There were two potential bidders and the ICC picked what it thought was the one that would restrict competition the least. The losing party filed a complaint before the District Dourt, alleging that the combination would violate Section 1 of the Sherman Act and Section 7 of the Clayton Act. District Court dismissed. Supreme Court affirms, saying that the ICC has exclusive jurisdiction over antitrust and that there was no clear error in the ICC decision

Title: Pittsburgh Plate Glass Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Petitioners were convicted of a single count for violating Section 1 of the Sherman Act. They affirmed an error of the trial judge by not allowing them to inspect the grand jury minutes before a key testimony. Court of appeals affirmed the conviction. Supreme Court affirms.

Title: Beacon Theatres, Inc. v. Westover
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Beacon threatened to sue Fox (Westover) for exclusivity in exhibiting first-run films in the San Bernardino area, in violation of Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. Fox then sued Beacon to declare that its contracts were legal. Beacon counterclaimed and demanded a jury trial, but the District Court denied. The Circuit court affirmed. Supreme Court reverses and affirms the right to a jury trial.

Title: F.T.C. v. Simplicity Pattern Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: FTC found Simplicity in violation of the Robinson-Patman act, one of the largest dress manufacturers in the US, by not furnishing all customers with the same access to services and facilities (larger customers had more access). It said that the discrimination could not be compensate by "cost justification" or the absence of competitive injury. Court of Appeals agreed on the competitive injury, but remanded the case for more information on the cost justification. FTC appealed. Supreme Court sides wiht the FTC, affirming that competition between two classes of customers is enough for "competitive injury" and that cost justifications only apply to price discriminations, and not to service access and others (different items of article 2 of the RPA).

Title: U.S. v. Parke, Davis & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sued Parke Davis for violating Section 1 and 3 of the Sherman Act by conspiring to maintain the wholesale and retail prices of its pharmaceutical products at minimum levels (minimum RPM). District Court dismissed without even hearing the defendant by claiming that the government failed to prove its case. DoJ appealed. Supreme Court sides with government, saying that the RPM is illegal if expressively found or if implied. The exception is the Colgate case, which the party simply announced the policy and then refused to deal with those that did not implementy it, without any form of communication or agreement. In this case there was clearly a combination between parke davis and wholesalers and retailers.

Title: Maryland and Virginia Milk Producers Ass'n v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sues milk cooperative that supplied 86% of the DC area for attempt to monopolize the market for fluid milk in DC, in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act. This is because the cooperative entered into agreements and bought assets of its main competitors, also in violation of Section 7 of the Clayton Act. Cooperative argued it was exempt from antitrust laws. District Court agreed on the formation of the cooperative (exempt) but found for the Government in relation to the acquisitions and order the cooperatie to divest the acquired assets and terminate contracts. Supreme Court finds for the Government in all counts

Title: Eastern R. R. Presidents Conference v. Noerr Motor Freight, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Association of truck drivers sued an association of railroad owners/operators for attempting to monopolize the long-distance freight business in violation of Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. The allegation was that the railroads had hired a public agent to sway laws and public policies in a way that was damaging for the truckers (weight limits, tax rates on heavy trucks, etc.). Railroads filled a counter-claim. District Court found for the truckers. Appeals Court upheld. Supreme Court says there is no Sherman Act violation for merely associating to promote the passage of a law or bill, and that this includes public campaigns for the passage of a Bill. Reverses

Title: U. S. v. Parke, Davis & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Another order on the Parke Davis case above, affirming the judgement again in the face of new evidence

Title: Radiant Burners, Inc. v. Peoples Gas Light & Coke Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Petitioner sued larger company and association for violation of Sherman Section 1. The claim was that the association certified gas burners, but that this was not neutral and was influenced by larger players. Petitioner had twice submitted its own gas burner, but given an unfair consideration. District Court and Appeals Court dismiss for faillure to state a claim. Supreme Court reverses, saying that this could be a conspiracy or a group boycott and that the trial should proceed.

Title: Tampa Elec. Co. v. Nashville Coal Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Powerplant built a new coal plant (innovation at the time) and contracted for coal supply for 20 years. Right when the contract was about to start being performed, the suppliers said the contract was illegal under antitrust laws and revoked it. The powerplant then sued to enforce the contract. District Court and Circuit Court agreed it was in violation of antitrust Laws (Section 3 of the Clayton Act). Supreme Court says the relevant market was supply of coal to all the US, and that the contracted impacted less than 1% of sales. Therefore, there is no relevant impact on the market. Reverses. CANNOT DETERMINE COMPANY SIZES

Title: U.S. v. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: After the DuPont case, District Court refuses government total divestiture of the position in GM. Government appeals. Supreme Court sides with Government on divestiture.

Title: U.S. v. Loew's, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sued several six major movie distributor for violating Sherman Act Section 1 due to their conditioning of licensing major films upon the display of lesser films as well. District Court found that while there was competition among distirbutors, there were individual tying violations for each licensing agreement. Enjoined tying in future contracts. Parties appeal. Supreme Court agrees it was tying. Also expand remedies in line with US more strict request of individual pricing for films and others

Title: Continental Ore Co. v. Union Carbide & Carbon Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Continental was a small supplier of ferrovanadium and vanadium oxide, and sued larger suppliers for attempting and conspiring to monopolize the trade and commerce, in violation of Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. This was through a series of acquisitions and contracts that excluded potential smaller competitors like Continental. Jury ruled in favor of defendants. Court of appeals affirmed. Supreme Court remands for new trial saying there was enough evidence for a direct veredict

Title: U.S. v. Wise
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Jury returned two counts against the National Dairy Products Corporation for violating Section 1 of the Sherman Act by engaging in a conspiracy to eliminate competition in the market for milk in the great Kansas City. Appellee was an employee that was also charged but Distrct Court dismissed because he was simply a representative of the company. Government appealed. Supreme Court says "persons" should be interpreted broadly, to also include corporate executives.

Title: Brown Shoe Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Government sues brown shoe company for violating Section 7 of the Clayton Act by merging with Kinney. Brown shoe was the 3rd largest seller of shoes by volume in the US, and Kinney was the 8th and itself a large manufacturer and retailer (though nationally it represented 0.5% of manufacturing and 2% of retail capacity). District Court enjoined the merger because of risk for the retail sector (not wholesale). Brownshoe was found to be a driver of the increased verticalization of the industry by acquiring many smaller companies and afterward increasing its supply to these companies. Still it had only 4% of manufacturing. Supreme Court affirms that there is no de minimis risk of foreclosure in vertical relations, and that one must consider economic and historical industry arrangements to understand whether the merger is harmful. This was a merger of large, leading companies in the sector that was mostly shaped as family-sized shops. This could increase the risk of foreclosure similar to a tying arrangement, and more dangerous in an industry that is tending to consolidation--and Congress intention was to prevent the formation of oligopolies in previoulsy competitive markets. In addition, in many local retail markets the concentration by volume would exceeed 20% of sales of shoes (cities like NY and others)and in some would exceed 57%. Affirms.

Title: Sunkist Growers, Inc. v. Winckler & Smith Citrus Products Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Charge of violation of Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act to restrain and monopolize the inter-state commerce of citrus fruits and byproducts. Sunkist (the defendant and petitioner) is an agricultural cooperative organization, which claims to be exempt from antitrust laws. Plaintiff is a customer, who alleges was offered oranges at artificially high prices due to the cooperative arrangements. Supreme Court affirms the exemption, overruling the District and Circuit Courts.

Title: Poller v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Question on whether companies were entitled to summary judgement in a case involving a dissolution of a company after FCC approval for an acquisition. Supreme Court rules they were not, reafirming the right of plaintiffs to trial

Title: Los Angeles Meat and Provision Drivers Union, Local 626 v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Violation of Section 1 of the Sherman Act in the monopolization of the market for yellow grease. In particular, the appellants were a Los Angeles labor union and some of its members/contractors who are so called grease peddlers. The union encourage most suppliers (workers in restaurants) to become members of the union so as to increase margins, fixed purchase and sales prices for members. District Court enjoyned the practice and barred membership to the Union as a remedy. Supreme Court agrees.

Title: U.S. v. Borden Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Robinson-Patman claim involving price discrimination of dairy products. District Court affirmed the discrimination under 2(a) but affirmed it was jusified for cost reasons. Government challenged the measure of cost used by the District Court. Supreme Court agrees with Government that the measure was erroneous

KeyCite.Treatment: Yellow KeyCite and Overruling Risk KeyCite
Title: White Motor Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sues truck and other car manufacturers for per se violations of the Sherman Act due to territorial exclusivity and other minimum price  clauses in their distribution agreements. District Court agreed in a summary judgment. Supreme Court affirms the summary judgement on price fixing, but says that while territorial restraints are per se violations, there should have been a trial to ascertain motivation, etc. Reverses

Title: U.S. v. Singer Mfg. Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sued a manufacturer of household zigzag sewing machines for violation of Section 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. The claim was a conspiracy between Singer and two other international companies to through cross-licensing agreements to exclude japanese manufacturers from the market. District court dismissess. Supreme Court reverses and declares a conspiracy

Title: Silver v. New York Stock Exchange
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: NYSE denied private telephone connections necessary for brokers to operate, in accordance with its rules. Plaintiff, a small broker, sues for violation of Sections 1 and 2. Exchange claims exemption based on the Securiities Act. District Court granted summary judgement to plaintiff, saying that the exchange could not regulate member-to-non member contracts.  Court of Appeals reversed. Supreme Court reverses, saying that exemption is only valid to the extent truly necessary to further the goals of the Securities and Exchange act.

Title: Pan Am. World Airways, Inc. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Over the request of the US Civil Aviation Board, US challenged PanAm control over air routes to South America, in particular because of a 50% share ownership in a joint-venture with antoher competitor and subsequente territorial divisions. This would be in violation of Sections 1, 2 and 3 of the Sherman Act. District Court granted only one count. Both US and Company appealed. Supreme Court says board would have the power to order the divestiture direclty and that this would exempt antitrust enforcement and so reverses and remands to order the divestiture.

Title: U.S. v. Philadelphia Nat. Bank
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sues under Section 1 of the Sherman Act and 7 of the Clayton Act to block a merger between two banks. District Court dismisses. Supreme Court reverts. Banks were the 2nd and 3rd largest in the Metropolitan Region of Philly (that had other 42 banks). After merger, the bank would be first with 36% share and the second largest would have together 59% of share of assets. The four largest would have 78%. The Comptroller approved the merger and the US sued the next day. Supreme Court first affirms that antitrust laws apply to banking (in particular Section 7) and that there is no exemption to banking. Then affirms a general fear of economic consolidation (as in Brown Shoe), so the creation of a leading firm with a significant increase in concentration can be blocked. Affirms this is the case here, as even though there are 40 other banks the goal of Section 7 was to "arrest the trend towards concentration" in markets before alternatives to consumers disappear. Supreme Court dismissess the defense that a stronger bank will be able to expand to better compete with banks in other areas, as "anticompetitive effects in one market" cannot be justified by pro-competitive effects in another>

Title: U.S. v. National Dairy Products Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sues national dairy for violation of Section 3 of the Robinson-Patman Act for selling milk below cost. Defendant claims that the provision making it illegal to sell at "unreasonably low prices for the pruposes of destroying competition or eliminating a competitor" is too vague and unconstitutional. District Court affirms unconstitutionality. Supreme Court reverses and affirms that "selling below cost" is included in "unreasonably low prices". Also affirms the requirement of predatory intent, though does not affirm a cost test. Also affirms that not all sales below cost are immediately illegal, as there must be intent.

Title: Simpson v. Union Oil Co. of Cal.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Union oil signs consignment agreements with its retailers. These are valid for one year and must be renewed. Simpson, a retailer, started selling above the fixed price (to meet competition) and Union Oil terminated his contract. He alleges that these agreements are a way for Union Oil to control retail gas prices and sues for violation of Sections I and II of the Sherman Act. District Court dismisses, so does Circuit Court. Supreme Court reverses, saying that if the coercively consignment agreement is just a subterfuge to fixed RPM and if there is interstate commerce impact, there is a violation.

Title: U. S. v. First Nat. Bank & Trust Co. of Lexington
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US alleges that the merger of two banks was a violation of Section 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. Comptroller approve. DoJ sues on the same day. District Court dismisses saying there is no proof of harm (but no immunity). Supreme Court reverses, alleging Section 1 harm

Title: U.S. v. Ward Baking Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US alleges cartel of bakeries against the Naval Base in the Jackson area. Bakeries proposed a settlement that the US rejected. Judge accepted the settlement anyway (without trial). US appeals. Supreme Court reverts settlement

Title: Hudson Distributors, Inc. v. Eli Lilly & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Eli Lilly manufacturs drugs and imposes RPM pursuant to na Ohio act that enables it. Lilly had no relationhip with retailers. Hudson, a retailer, refuses to accept the RPM. Lilly notifies. Hudson sues for violation of the Sherman Act. Ohio courts disagree, saying the statute was constitutional. Supreme Court upholds saying that the McGuire Act exempted State fair trade laws from antitrust enforcement.

Title: U.S. v. Penn-Olin Chemical Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Government sues to dissolve a joint venture that controles the sale of sodium chlorate in SE US. Trial court said there was no antitrust violation. Government appealed. Supreme Court clarifies that Section 7 applies to JVs, reverts and remands for new analysis.

Title: U.S. v. Welden
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: US sues individual for price fixing of milk. Individual moves to dismiss because he had testified to Congress on the matter. District Court grants dismissal. US appeals. Supreme Court reverts.

Title: U.S. v. Aluminum Co. of America
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The question is whether the 1959 acquisition by the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) of the stock and assets of the Rome Cable Corporation (Rome) "may be substantially to lessen competition, or to tend to create a monopoly" in the production and sale of various wire and cable products and accessories within the meaning of § 7 of the Clayton Act.[1] The United States, claiming that § 7 had been violated, instituted this civil suit and prayed for divestiture. The District Court, after a trial, held that there was no violation and dismissed the complaint. 214 F. Supp. 501. The case is here on appeal. Supreme Court reverts and orders sale of acquired company.

Title: United Mine Workers of America v. Pennington
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Smaller coal producer sues larger producer for monopolization of coal business by agreeing with the Union on price increases (not flexibe), increased mechanization and others. These would drive smaller companies out of business and increase the market power of larger suppliers. District Court and judge ruled for plaintiff and granted treble damages. Court of Appeals affirmed. Supreme Court affirms that while the contract itself was not exempt from antitrust laws because impacted the whole industry, but says that Noerr shielded joint-conduct to influece the views of public officials even if intended to eliminate competition. In this case, the contract was approved by the NLRB and the trial Court did not properly consider this as a potential exemption. So reverts and remands.

Title: Walker Process Equipment, Inc. v. Food Machinery & Chemical Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The question before us is whether the maintenance and enforcement of a patent obtained by fraud on the Patent Office may be the basis of an action under § 2 of the Sherman Act,[1] and therefore subject to a treble damage claim by an injured party under § 4 of the Clayton Act. District Court and Circuit Court say no. Supreme Court says it can be a violation and subject to treble damages if other characteristics of Section 2 voiolation are present. Reverses and remands

Title: Local Union No. 189, Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, AFL-CIO v. Jewel Tea Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Supermarket sues union for violation of Sherman Act for the restriction on the operating hours of food store meat departments contained in a collective bargaining agreement executed after joint multi-employer, multi-union negotiations. District Court says that contracts are not totally exempt from antitrust, but that in this case there was no evidence of conspiracy and contract was within Union's interest in protecting workers (so, exempt). Circuit Court reverses. Supreme Court reverses again, saying that while there is no broad exemption there was in this case.

Title: Leh v. General Petroleum Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: On September 28, 1956, petitioners, a partnership engaged in wholesale distribution of refined petroleum products and one of the partners, filed in the Southern District of California a treble-damage action charging violations of §§ 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. §§ 1, 2 (1964 ed.), against seven companies engaged in producing, refining, and marketing gasoline and other hydrocarbon substances in interstate commerce. Defendants contended that the action was barred by the California one-year statute of limitations applicable to suits for statutory penalties or forfeitures, Cal. Code Civ. Proc. § 340 (1). Argument was that a civil lawsuit initiated by the US interrupted the statute of limitations. District Court dismisses the lawsuit. Supreme Court reverses

Title: Minnesota Min. & Mfg. Co. v. New Jersey Wood Finishing Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Company brings a treble action lawsuit after a supplier buys all the assets of another supplier (market of electrical insullation materials). Defense is the statute of limitations. Plaintiff affirms it has been lifted because FTC started a litigation with order for divestiture. District Court and Appeals Court agree with plaintiff and grants treble damages. Supreme Court says FTC actions also stop statute of limitations. Affirms.

Title: U.S. v. General Motors Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This is a civil action brought by the United States to enjoin the appellees from participating in an alleged conspiracy to restrain trade in violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act. GM had franchise agreements that limited dealers from moving location without authorization (did not restrition the territory they may sell to). GM used it to prevent sales to discounters that were removing sales from dealers. US sues the vertical relation as violation of Section 1. Supreme Court affirms this is a classic conspiracy, reverses district Court and rules for the government.

Title: U.S. v. Grinnell Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Grinnel manufactures plumbing supplies and owns the stock of several other companies that operate in markets for burgler and fire alarm services that connect through a single central station. Grinnel has a leading position in the central station market through many acquisitions of smaller competitors. Companies also were part of a 1906 agreement that restricted and divided markets markets. Grinnel also had vertical agreements to supply Sprinkler services to some competitors. US sues for violation of Section 1 and 2. District Court agrees its per se violations. Supreme Court affirms, holding that: "The offense of monopoly under § 2 of the Sherman Act has two elements: (1) the possession of monopoly power in the relevant market and (2) the willful acquisition 571*571 or maintenance of that power as distinguished from growth or development as a consequence of a superior product, business acumen, or historic accident. We shall see that this second ingredient presents no major problem here, as what was done in building the empire was done plainly and explicitly for a single purpose. In United States v. du Pont & Co., 351 U. S. 377, 391, we defined monopoly power as "the power to control prices or exclude competition." The existence of such power ordinarily may be inferred from the predominant share of the market. In American Tobacco Co. v. United States, 328 U. S. 781, 797, we said that "over two-thirds of the entire domestic field of cigarettes, and . . . over 80% of the field of comparable cigarettes" constituted "a substantial monopoly." In United States v. Aluminum Co. of America, 148 F. 2d 416, 429, 90% of the market constituted monopoly power. In the present case, 87% of the accredited central station service business leaves no doubt that the congeries of these defendants have monopoly power—power which, as our discussion of the record indicates, they did not hesitate to wield—if that business is the relevant market."

Title: Carnation Co. v. Pacific Westbound Conference
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether the Shipping Act precludes the enforcement of antitrust laws. Shipper had a lot of business between the west-coast and Asia. A conference of shippers, with tariffs approved by the Federal Maritime Commission, then increases rate (pending approval). Customer sues for antitrust violation and treble damages. Respondents claim Shipping Act precludes antitrust. District and Circuit court agreed. Supreme Court reverts saying that if the Commission has not yet approved the price changes, they are subject to antitrust laws.

Title: U. S. v. Von's Grocery Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Von's grocery acquires direct competitor Shopping Bag Food. US sues as violation of the Clayton Act. District Court dismissed given no probable injury to competition. Both companies were rapidly growing, but accounted for only 7.5% of retail in Los Angeles and were not market leaders. Supreme Court says the market appears to be consolidating, that the antitrust laws were partially aimed at protecting small businessmen and preventing harmful consolidation, and reverts--ordering the divestiture. Appellees' primary argument is that the merger between Von's and Shopping Bag is not prohibited by § 7 because the Los Angeles grocery market was competitive before the merger, has been since, and may continue to be in the future. Even so, § 7 "requires not merely an appraisal of the immediate impact of the merger upon competition, but a prediction of its impact upon competitive conditions in the future; this is what is meant when it is said that the amended § 7 was intended to arrest anticompetitive tendencies in their `incipiency.' " U. S. v. Philadelphia Nat. Bank, 374 U. S. 321, 362. It is enough for us that Congress feared that a market marked at the same time by both a continuous decline in the number of small businesses and a large number of mergers would slowly but inevitably gravitate from a market of many small competitors to one dominated by one or a few giants, and competition would thereby be destroyed.

Title: F.T.C. v. Brown Shoe Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: FTC sues Brownshoe Co., one of the US largest shoe manufacturers, for its franchising practices  that prevented franchisees from buying and selling shoes from competitors, in exchange for better terms and preferential treatment. FTC said this was an unfair method of competition that violated Section 5 of the FTC Act. Appeals Court reverts. Supreme Court confirms the FTC saying there was clearly a vertical agreement and that Brown Shoe had market power. Affirms that the FTC has broad powers to find violations

Title: U. S. v. Pabst Brewing Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Pabst, 10th largest brewery in the US, acquired the 18th. US sues as violation of the Clayton Act for risk to the Wisconsin market. District court dismisses under relevant market jurisdiction. Supreme Court says that not all cases need precise relevant marktes when there is evidence of harm. Also holds that "We hold that a trend toward 553*553 concentration in an industry, whatever its causes, is a highly relevant factor in deciding how substantial the anticompetitive effect of a merger may be". Reverts.

Title: F.T.C. v. Borden Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Borden sold powder milk as of its own brand and cheaper as part of private label. The product was the same, but prices were different. FTC sues for violation of Section of the Robinson Patman Act as discriminatory pricing. Court of Appeals dismissed, saying that as a matter of law products were different because different brands enabled different customer acceptance. Supreme Court affirms the FTC.

KeyCite.Treatment: Yellow KeyCite and Overruling Risk KeyCite
Title: U.S. v. Sealy, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: In this civil action the United States charged that appellee had violated § 1 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. § 1, by conspiring with its licensees to fix the prices at which the retail customers of the licensees might resell bedding products bearing the Sealy name, and to allocate mutually exclusive territories among such manufacturer-licensees. District Court affirmed the violation on price fixing, but dismissed on territorial restraints. Supreme Court says it is a horizontal restraint because most licensees own the stock of the supplier company. Affirms Per Se violation and reverts district court.

Title: Burke v. Ford
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Petitioners, Oklahoma liquor retailers, brought this action under § 1 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, 15 U. S. C. § 1, to enjoin an alleged state-wide market division by all Oklahoma liquor wholesalers. The trial judge, sitting without a jury, found that there had in fact been a division of markets—both by territories and by brands. The court nevertheless entered judgment for the wholesalers because, among other reasons, it found that the interstate commerce prerequisite of the Sherman Act was not satisfied. The Court of Appeals affirmed upon the sole ground that "the proof was entirely insufficient to show that the activities complained of were in or adversely affected interstate commerce." Supreme Court reverts because all liquor is imported into Oklahoma, so there is clearly interstate commerce.

Title: U. S. v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The complaint charged a continuing conspiracy since 1952 between defendants and other alleged co-conspirators involving price fixing, allocation of exclusive territories to wholesalers and jobbers, and confinement of merchandise to franchised dealers. The District Court rejected the charge of price fixing. With respect to the charges of illegal distribution practices, the court held that the territorial limitation was 368*368 unlawful per se as respects products sold by Schwinn to its distributors; but that the limitation was not unlawful insofar as it was incident to sales by Schwinn itself to franchised retailers where the wholesaler or jobber (hereinafter referred to as the distributor) functioned as agent or consignee, including distribution pursuant to the "Schwinn Plan". Schwinn was a leading company in the 50s, but by the 60s strong compettiion had emerged (it had a 13% market share). The United States does not contend that there is in this case any restraint on interbrand competition, nor does it attempt to sustain its charge by reference to the market for bicycles as a whole. Instead, it invites us to confine our attention to the intrabrand effect of the contested restrictions. It urges us to declare that the 370*370 method of distribution of a single brand of bicycles, amounting to less than one-seventh of the market, constitutes an unreasonable restraint of trade or commerce among the several States. Supreme Court affirms that there is no restriction of competition on the Schwinn Plan, when the bycicles were consigned to agents, but that there is one (under rule of reason) on limitations on wholesale distributors that actually acquired the bycicles. Affirms that under the rule of reason there is no evidence that the Schwinn Plan was harmful to competition. Reverses in part and affirms in part.

Title: Case-Swayne Co. v. Sunkist Growers, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This is a treble-damage action under § 4 of the Clayton Act, 38 Stat. 731, 15 U. S. C. § 15, for alleged violations of both § 1 and § 2 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. §§ 1, 2. The District Court granted a directed verdict, at the close of plaintiff's case, for the defendant, Sunkist Growers, Inc. The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed as to that portion of the complaint predicated on § 2 of the Sherman Act, holding that sufficient evidence was presented that Sunkist monopolized or attempted to monopolize trade in the relevant market;[1] it affirmed as to the dismissal of the Sherman Act § 1 charge, holding that Sunkist qualified as a cooperative organization under the Capper-Volstead Act, 42 Stat. 388, 7 U. S. C. § 291,[2] and therefore could not be held for any intraorganizational conspiracy to restrain trade. In order to determine the scope of that exemption from the antitrust laws, we granted certiorari. The issue is whether Sunkist is an association of "[p]ersons engaged in the production of agricultural products as . . . fruit growers" within the meaning of the Capper-Volstead Act, notwithstanding that certain of its members are not actually growers. We hold that it is not.

Title: Utah Pie Co. v. Continental Baking Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Smaller pie company (Utah pie) sues larger pie companies for violation of the Robinson Patman Act for the selling of frozen dessert pies at lower prices in Utah  than in other US States that were much closer to their manufacturing plants (none located in Utah). Utah Pie sues. Jury found for respondents on conspiracy charge but for Utah Pie on price discrimination. Appeals Court reversed saying not harm to competition. We again differ with the Court of Appeals. Its opinion that Utah was not damaged as a competitive force apparently rested on the fact that Utah's sales volume continued to climb in 1961 and on the court's own factual conclusion that Utah was not deprived of any pie business which it otherwise might have had. But this retrospective assessment fails to note that Continental's discriminatory below-cost price caused Utah Pie to reduce its price to $2.75. The jury was entitled to consider the potential impact of Continental's price reduction absent any responsive price cut by Utah Pie.

Title: Denver & R. G. W. R. Co. v. U. S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: ICC approved the partial acquisition of a railway by a competitor. Question is whether this violated the Clayton Act. This approval was without a hearing, despite protests from the DoJ. Competitor sue, and the question is whether the partial acquisition, which took place through the issuance of new stocks, is precluded from antitrust review even when the ICC did not consider the competitive impact in its approval analysis. District Court says yes. Supreme Court reverts and says a hearing on the topic was needed.

Title: U.S. v. First City Nat. Bank of Houston
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: These civil suits were filed by the United States under § 7 of the Clayton Act, 38 Stat. 731, as amended, 64 Stat. 1125, 15 U. S. C. § 18, to prevent two bank mergers—one in Texas between the First City National Bank of Houston and the Southern National Bank of Houston, and one in Pennsylvania between the Provident National Bank and the Central Penn National Bank, both in Philadelphia. the OCC approved both. District Court dismissed both lawsuits. Supreme Court says antitrust laws are applicable.

Title: Albrecht v. Herald Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Respondent publishes the Globe-Democrat, a morning newspaper distributed in the St. Louis metropolitan area by independent carriers who buy papers at wholesale and sell them at retail. There are 172 home delivery routes. Respondent advertises a suggested retail price in its newspaper. Carriers have exclusive territories which are subject to termination if prices exceed the suggested maximum. Petitioner, who had Route 99, adhered to the advertised price for some time but in 1961 raised the price to customers.[2] After more than once objecting to this practice, respondent wrote petitioner on May 20, 1964, that because he was overcharging and because respondent had reserved the right to compete should that happen, subscribers on Route 99 were being informed by letter that respondent would itself deliver the paper to those who wanted it at the lower price. As a result, about 300 of petitioner's 1,200 customers switched to direct delivery by respondent. Meanwhile, respondent continued to sell papers to petitioner but warned him that should he continue to overcharge, respondent would not have to do business with him. Since respondent did not itself want to engage in home delivery, it advertised a new route of 314 customers as available without cost. Another carrier, George Kroner, took over the route. A jury returned a verdict for respondent in petitioner's suit for treble damages for violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act.[1] Judgment was entered on the verdict against the plaintiff for faillure to state a case and the Court of Appeals for the Eighth circuit affirmed. 367 F. 2d 517 (1966). The question is whether the denial of petitioner's motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict was correctly affirmed by the Court of Appeals. Supreme Court reverses, says this is a clear case of per se violation.

Title: American Federation of Musicians of U. S. and Canada v. Carroll
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This action for injunctive relief and treble damages alleging violations of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. §§ 1 and 2, was brought in the District Court for the Southern District of New York against the petitioners in No. 309, American Federation of Musicians and its Local 802.[1] The question is whether union practices of the petitioners affecting orchestra leaders violate the Sherman Act as activities in combination with a "non-labor" group, or are exempted by the Norris-LaGuardia Act as activities affecting a "labor" group which is party to a "labor dispute."[2] After a 102*102 five-week trial without a jury the District Court dismissed the action on the merits, holding that all of the petitioners' practices brought in question "come within the definition of the term `labor dispute' . . . and are exempt from the antitrust laws." 241 F. Supp. 865, 894. The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed on the issue of alleged price fixing, but in all other respects affirmed the dismissal. We hold that the District Court properly dismissed the action on the merits, and that the Court of Appeals should have affirmed the District Court judgment in its entirety--practice was a labor dispute exempt from antitrust laws.

Title: Hanover Shoe, Inc. v. United Shoe Machinery Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Hanover Shoe, Inc. (hereafter Hanover) is a manufacturer of shoes and a customer of United Shoe Machinery Corporation (hereafter United), a manufacturer and distributor of shoe machinery. In 1954 this Court affirmed the judgment of the District Court for the District of Massachusetts, 110 F. Supp. 295 (1953), in favor of the United States in a civil action against United under § 4 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, 15 U. S. C. § 4. United Shoe Machinery Corp. v. United States, 347 U. S. 521. In 1955, Hanover brought the present treble-damage action against United in the District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania. In 1965 the District Court rendered judgment for Hanover and awarded trebled damages, including interest, of $4,239,609, as well as $650,000 in counsel fees. 245 F. Supp. 258. On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit affirmed the finding of liability but disagreed with the District Court on certain questions relating to the damage award. Question is on whether a party convicted of an antitrust violation can claim a pass-on defense: the damages are smaller because the party passed on the increase in costs. Supreme Court says no, partially reverts the Circuit Court decision

Title: U.S. v. United Shoe Machinery Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses remedy in the previous United Shoe case. District Court, following the supreme court, denied divestiture and accepted less stringent requirements. After the decree failed, government sued again for divestutute, but District Court said it did not have the powers to alter the original degree as there was no error in law. US appeals. Supreme Court sides with US, says the District Court has to analyze whether the remedies are achieving their goals.

Title: U.S. v. Third Nat. Bank in Nashville
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: In this case the United States appeals from a District Court decision[1] upholding the merger of Third National Bank in Nashville and Nashville Bank and Trust Company against challenge under § 7 of the Clayton Act. The court below concluded that the merger, which joined the second largest and the fourth largest banks in Davidson County, Tennessee, into a bank which immediately after the merger was the county's largest bank but since has become the second largest, would not tend substantially to lessen competition and also that any anticompetitive effect would be outweighed by the "convenience and needs of the community to be served." We disagree with the District Court on both issues. We hold that the United States established that this merger would tend to lessen competition, and also that the District Court did not point to community benefits in terms of "convenience and needs" sufficient to outweigh the anticompetitive impact.

Title: Perma Life Mufflers, Inc. v. International Parts Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The principal question presented is whether the plaintiffs in this private antitrust action were barred from recovery by a doctrine known by the Latin phrase in pari delicto, which literally means "of equal fault." The plaintiffs, petitioners here, were all dealers who had operated "Midas Muffler Shops" under sales agreements granted by respondent Midas, Inc. Their complaint charged that Midas had entered into a conspiracy with the other named defendants—its parent corporation International Parts Corp., two other subsidiaries, and six individual defendants who were officers or agents of the corporations—to restrain and substantially lessen competition in violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act[1] and § 3 of the Clayton Act.[2] They also charged that the defendants had violated § 2 (a) of the Clayton Act, as amended by the Robinson-Patman Act,[3] by granting discriminations in prices and services to some of their customers without offering the same advantages to the plaintiffs. The District Court entered summary judgment for respondents with respect to all of petitioners' 136*136 claims. On appeal the Court of Appeals reversed the judgment for respondents on the Robinson-Patman claim but, over Judge Cummings' dissent, affirmed the District Court's ruling that the other claims were barred by the doctrine of in pari delicto. we reverse. Affirms that broad common law defenses are not applicable to antitrust lawsuits with specific purpose and Congress approval.

Title: U. S. v. Concentrated Phosphate Export Ass'n
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Involved in this case are 11 sales of concentrated phosphate made between 1961 and 1966 by appellee association. The phosphate was supplied by the association's members,[1] which are all producers of fertilizer, and was then shipped to the Republic of Korea under the United States foreign aid program. The Government, in a civil antitrust complaint filed on December 21, 1964, contended that the concerted activities of the association and its members in regard to these 11 sales violated § 1 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209 (1890), as amended, 15 U. S. C. § 1. Appellees defended on the ground, inter alia, that their activities were exempted from antitrust liability by § 2 of the Webb-Pomerene Act, 40 Stat. 517 (1918), 15 U. S. C. § 62,[2] as "act[s] done in the course of export trade." The trial court held that the Webb-Pomerene Act did immunize appellees' conduct, 273 F. Supp. 263 (1967), and dismissed the complaint. 202*202 The Government perfected a direct appeal to this Court under the Expediting Act, 32 Stat. 823. Supreme Court reverts because the acquisition was made by the Government within the US, so it was not for purposes of export trade as deemed in the act

Title: First Nat. Bank of Ariz. v. Cities Service Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: At issue in this case is the propriety of an award of summary judgment in favor of respondent Cities Service in a treble-damage antitrust action. The District Court held there was no genuine issue as to material facts between the parties and that respondent was entitled to judgment as a matter of law. 38 F. R. D. 170 (D. C. S. D. N. Y. 1965). The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed. 361 F. 2d 671 (1966). This Court granted certiorari, 385 U. S. 1024 (1967), to determine whether the decisions below were in conformity with Poller v. Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., 368 U. S. 464 (1962). We conclude that Poller and other decisions of this Court were correctly applied and, accordingly, we affirm. Cases discusses an alleged cartel by oil companies.

Title: F.T.C. v. Fred Meyer, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The Federal Trade Commission, after extensive proceedings, ruled that respondents, the corporate owner of a chain of supermarkets and two of its officers, had unlawfully induced certain suppliers to engage in discriminatory pricing and sales promotional activities prohibited by §§ 2 (a) and 2 (d) of the Clayton Act, as amended 343*343 by the Robinson-Patman Act.[1] 63 F. T. C. ___ (1963). The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit disagreed with the Commission's construction of § 2 (d) and reversed in part its ruling that the section had been violated. 359 F. 2d 351 (1966). We granted certiorari, 386 U. S. 907 (1967), because the case presents important questions concerning the scope of a key provision of the Robinson-Patman Act. Meyer had a discount system in which customers bought a coupon book for items. The sale was financed by the suppliers of the supermarket paying the supermarket to participate, and by granting them discoounts. FTC sues the supermarket and the suppliers saying that both the payment and the extra discounts violated the Robinson Patman Act. Supreme Court sides with the Commission

Title: Fortner Enterprises, Inc. v. U.S. Steel Corp.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This case raises a variety of questions concerning the proper standards to be applied by a United States district court in passing on a motion for summary judgment in a civil antitrust action. Petitioner, Fortner Enterprises, Inc., filed this suit seeking treble damages and an injunction against alleged violations of §§ 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. §§ 1, 2. The complaint charged that respondents, United States Steel Corp. and its wholly owned subsidiary, the United States Steel Homes Credit 497*497 Corp., had engaged in a contract, combination, and conspiracy to restrain trade and to monopolize trade in the sale of prefabricated houses. It alleged that there was a continuing agreement between respondents "to force corporations and individuals, including the plaintiff, as a condition to availing themselves of the services of United States Steel Homes Credit Corporation, to purchase at artificially high prices only United States Steel Homes . . . ." Specifically, petitioner claimed that in order to obtain loans totaling over $2,000,000 from the Credit Corp. for the purchase and development of certain land in the Louisville, Kentucky, area, it had been required to agree, as a condition of the loans, to erect a prefabricated house manufactured by U. S. Steel on each of the lots purchased with the loan proceeds. Petitioner claimed that the prefabricated materials were then supplied by U. S. Steel at unreasonably high prices and proved to be defective and unusable, thus requiring the expenditure of additional sums and delaying the completion date for the development. Petitioner sought treble damages for the profits thus lost, along with a decree enjoining respondents from enforcing the requirement of the loan agreement that petitioner use only houses manufactured by U. S. Steel. After pretrial proceedings in which a number of affidavits and answers to interrogatories were filed, the District Court entered summary judgment for respondents, holding that petitioner's allegations had failed to raise any question of fact as to a possible violation of the antitrust laws. Noting that the agreement involved here was essentially a tying arrangement, under which the purchaser was required to take a tied product—here prefabricated homes—as a condition of being allowed to purchase the tying product—here credit, the District Judge held that petitioner had failed to establish the prerequisites of illegality under our tying cases, namely 498*498 sufficient market power over the tying product and foreclosure of a substantial volume of commerce in the tied product. The Court of Appeals affirmed without opinion, and we granted certiorari, 393 U. S. 820 (1968). Since we find no basis for sustaining this summary judgment, we reverse and order that the case proceed to trial.

Title: Citizen Pub. Co. v. U.S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The two only competing newspapers formed a new company to handle their business matters (printing, distribution, pricing) but maintaned the newsroom independent. There was joint distribution of profits, which increased a lot. US sues for violation of Section 1, 2 and Section 7. District Court sides with the Government and orders divestiture. Newspapers appeal. Supreme Court confirms the ruling

Title: U.S. v. Container Corp. of America
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This is a civil antitrust action charging a price-fixing agreement in violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act.[1] 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. § 1. The District Court dismissed the complaint. Here all that was present was a request by each defendant of its competitor for information as to the most recent price charged or quoted, whenever it needed such information and whenever it was not available from another source. Each defendant on receiving that request usually furnished the data with the expectation that it would be furnished reciprocal information when it wanted it.[2] That concerted action is of course sufficient to establish the combination or conspiracy, the initial ingredient of a violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act. Supreme Court reverses and sides with Government. We cannot agree that on the record before the District Court a jury could not have found that the respondents had conspired to exclude the petitioner from and monopolize the market for bronze grave markers. Reverses

Title: Norfolk Monument Co. v. Woodlawn Memorial Gardens, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: The petitioner, a retailer of burial monuments and bronze grave markers, brought this action for damages and injunctive relief under §§ 4 and 16 of the Clayton Act, 38 Stat. 731, 737, as amended, 15 U. S. C. §§ 15, 26, 701*701 alleging that the respondents had violated §§ 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act, 26 Stat. 209, as amended, 15 U. S. C. §§ 1, 2, by conspiring to monopolize and monopolizing the manufacture and sale of bronze grave markers. The respondents—Matthews, a manufacturer of such markers, and five operators of cemeteries (called "memorial parks") that sell the markers—were charged with having jointly adopted various restrictive devices to prevent, restrict, and discourage sales of markers by the petitioner for installation in the cemeteries. After extensive pretrial discovery, the District Court granted the respondents' motion for summary judgment, concluding that there was no material issue of fact and no evidence of conspiracy. Supreme Court reverts

Title: Zenith Radio Corp. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Complex case involving a company that licensed a patent from Hazeltine, which was part of a broader group. After some years, Zenith affirmed Hazeltine that it did not require the patents anymore. Hazeltine sue for patent violation and organized with its corporate parents to deny other licenses to Zenith by international patent pools that involved its counterparts (part of the same group). Zenith seus for treble damanges for patent infringement and antitrust conspiracy. District Court grants the lawsuit and accepts antitrust violation and treble damages. Appeals Court reverses partially, removing the treble damages and an injuction that impeded the international patent pool from being organized. Supreme Court partially reverses the Appeals Court ruling, says there are many matters of fact and sends the case back.

Title: Simpson v. Union Oil Co. of Cal.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Follows from previous litigation. District and Circuit court denied damages for antitrust violation. Supreme Court reverses.

Title: Utah Public Service Commission v. El Paso Natural Gas Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This is a Clayton Act § 7 case, 38 Stat. 731, 15 U. S. C. § 18, in which the acquisition of the stock and assets of Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation by El Paso Natural Gas Company raised the "ultimate issue" whether "the acquisition substantially lessened competition in the sale of natural gas in California." United States v. El Paso Natural Gas Co., 376 U. S. 651, 652. We ordered divestiture "without delay." Id., at 662. That was in 1964. The United States later agreed to settle the case. Utah's jurisdictional statement, which she now moves to dismiss, was filed here November 25, 1968. That jurisdictional statement presents the question whether the decree entered below satisfies our mandate. It is the filing of that jurisdictional statement that brings the question here. See United States v. du Pont & Co., 366 U. S. 316. In fact, in its jurisdictional statement, Utah urged that the decree does not meet the requirements of du Pont. We thus need not decide whether the papers filed by amicus curiae or Mr. Bennett properly presented the question of compliance. We find that the decree of the District Court does not comply with our mandate: it does not apportion the gas reserves between El Paso and New Company in a manner consistent with the purpose of the mandate, and it does not provide for complete divestiture. We therefore vacate the judgment and remand the case for further proceedings.

Title: U.S. v. I. C. C.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: After careful review, ICC approved a merger of railways. US challenged the approval under antitrust laws. District Court affirms exemption, and the Supreme Court confirms. Most of the discussion is on how the railway act should interpret antitrust laws.

Title: Ramsey v. United Mine Workers of America
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Petitioners, coal mine operators in southeastern Tennessee, were plaintiffs in the trial court, where their complaint accused respondent United Mine Workers of America of violating the Sherman Act by conspiring with various coal producers to drive petitioners out of business. The major thrust of the claim was that the Union had expressly or impliedly agreed with the major producers to impose the provisions of the National Bituminous Coal Wage Agreement (NBCWA), first executed by the Union and certain companies in 1950, on all coal mine operators, knowing that small and nonmechanized operators would be unable to meet the contract's terms. The purpose of this alleged conspiracy was to eliminate the marginal operators, control production, and reserve the market for larger concerns. The claim of express agreement rested on the so-called Protective Wage Clause (PWC) added to the NBCWA by amendment in 1958. The PWC, after reciting that the parties agreed that coal mines "shall be so operated as not to debase or lower the standards of wages, hours, safety requirements and other conditions of work, established by this contract,". After a long trial, District Court found no conspiracy. Appeals court agreed, but on a split en banc hearing. Supreme Court says that the correct standard to evaluate a conspiracy involving a Union is not "clear proof" for finding a violating, but preponderance of the evidence. Reverses.

Title: Haywood v. National Basketball Ass'n
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Question is on whether the NBA mandatory draft is a group boycott in violation of Section 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act. The litigation happened while the playoffs were taking place. District Court prevents the NBA from excluding the player, but circuit court reverses. Supreme Court sides with player and reinstates the injuction.

Title: U.S. v. Armour & Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: A company subject to an antitrust decree buys another company. Government sues, arguing that Greyhound should have been brought before the District Court (which retained permanent jurisdiction over the decree pursuant to § 5[5] of the Sherman Act). It asks the court to enjoin the company from acting to exercise control over or influence the business affairs of Armour, and be required to divest itself of the Armour stock. The contention is that the acquisition violates the decree since it causes Armour to be engaged in activities prohibited by the decree. The claim is that Greyhound is engaged in businesses that the decree prohibits Armour from being engaged in and the decree's purported purpose of separating the meatpackers from the retail food business is thus circumvented. Supreme Court says that the government is going beyond the decree.

Title: U.S. v. Greater Buffalo Press, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: This is a civil antitrust case brought by the United States charging a violation of § 7 of the Clayton Act,[1] as amended, 64 Stat. 1125, 15 U. S. C. § 18. The main thrust of the case involves the acquisition by Greater Buffalo Press, Inc. (Greater Buffalo), of all the stock of International Color Printing Co. (International). The complaint, at the secondary level, charged that Greater Buffalo, Hearst Corp., through its unincorporated division King Features Syndicate (King), Newspaper Enterprise Association, Inc. (NEA), and others had conspired to restrain the sale to newspapers of the printing of comic supplements in violation of § 1 of the Sherman Act, as amended, 26 Stat. 209, 15 U. S. C. § 1. It also charged that Hearst and NEA were violators of certain tying arrangements involving the licensing of comic features and the sale of comic supplements. After full trial the District Court dismissed the complaint.[3] The case came here under § 2 of the Expediting Act. Supreme Court says the acquisition violated the Clayton Actt

Title: Zenith Radio Corp. v. Hazeltine Research, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Follow-up from litigation above. It relates to whether the District Court accepted specific arguments in favor of Hazeltine that lowered Zenith awards. District Court sides with Zenith, Circuit court with Hazeltine, Supreme Court with Zenith again.

Title: U.S. v. Topco Associates, Inc.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: TOPCO is an association of supermarkets for purposes of acquiring goods. It is sued for violating Section 1 of the Sherman Act (in particular for territorial licenses and restriction of wholesale sales of TOPCO private label branded products). TOPCO members had a 10% market share (maximum). Court affirms a per se violation and revers District Court (which had affirmed rule of reason).

Title: U. S. v. Standard Oil Co. of Cal.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether US Antitrust Laws apply to the American Samoa. Courts conclude that probably yes, and reverse judgement saying no

Title: Ford Motor Co. v. U. S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether Ford violated the Celler-Keafauver Act by acquiring certain assets of a company, such as a trade name, battery plan and distribution of batteries. Case involves aftermarkets.  And vertical relations. Supreme Court affirms it violates the law, in a brown shoe style decision. Orders divestiture and stops Ford from manufacturing competing products for 10 years

Title: Hawaii v. Standard Oil Co. of Cal.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses the power of the State of Havaii as Parens patriae in a class action against over-charged consumers for petroleum products under Federal antitrust laws. Discussion is about "business or property" injury. Court affirms that State may sue for treble damages if its commercial interests are impacted, but not under parens patriae

Title: Tidewater Oil Co. v. U. S.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: BORDERLINE: Discusses whether the FTC can expedite civil antitrust lawsuits under the Expediting Act and Evans Act. Borderline: discusses antitrust, but it is very procedural. Ultimately, facilitates governemntal civil antitrust litigation

Title: California Motor Transport Co. v. Trucking Unlimited
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether associations have a right of petition before regulatory agencies and other administrative bodies, in expansion or not of the Noerr-Pennington doctrine that exempts petition before Congress. Says that there are limits to the doctrine and to the 1st amendment, and that petitioning to exclude competitors can violate antitrust laws

Title: Flood v. Kuhn
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
Why: Discusses whether baseball rules are exempt from Federal antitrust and other laws (in particular the collective bargaining agreements). SC affirms exemption

Title: F.T.C. v. Sperry & Hutchinson Co.
Court.Line: Supreme Court of the United States
